title: Abusing URL Parsers by long schema name

profile.name: curl
profile.about: cURL is a computer software project providing a library and command-line tool for transferring data using various protocols.

vulnerability_information:
## Summary:
There is known technique to exploit inconsistency of URL parser and URL requester logic to perform Server Side Request Forgery attack. Firstly it was presented by Orange Tsai at [A New Era Of SSRF Exploiting URL Parser](https://www.blackhat.com/docs/us-17/thursday/us-17-Tsai-A-New-Era-Of-SSRF-Exploiting-URL-Parser-In-Trending-Programming-Languages.pdf). Firstly I found the familiar issue at old versions of curl, but exploit did not seems works at latest releases. But now I'm ready to share new exploit of issue.

## Steps To Reproduce:
Schema parser logic of curl library is vulnerable to "Abusing URL Parsers". Malicious user can use this weakness to bypass whitelist protection and perform Server Side Request Forgery against targets, that use vulnerable version of library.

  1. curl "ssrf3.twowaysyncapp.tk://google.com"  Protocol "ssrf3.twowaysyncapp.tk" not supported or disabled in libcurl
  1. curl "aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa.twowaysyncapp.tk://google.com" Host aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa.twowaysyncapp.tk requested

## Supporting Material/References:
Details about attack presented at https://btlfry.gitlab.io/owasp/#/21 The main difference at new version of library subdomain name should be much longer.

  * F1102530

## Impact

Incorrect schema parser logic will allow malicious user to bypass protection mechanism and get access to the internal infrastructure of affected web servers.

activities.message: Thanks for you report, we will investigate and get back to you.
Thanks, we'll investigate!

This is a tricky one but I disagree somewhat with the description.

A primary reason this problem exists, is because curl supports scheme-less "URLs" for legacy reasons. Otherwise curl could've just bailed out when no known prefix was found. As it is now, it tries to detect a scheme but since the "scan" is restricted in length, it detects no valid scheme and instead moves on as if there is no scheme and then the "aaaa"-part becomes a host name.

Compare to `localhost://google.com` where we want to connect to the host 'localhost' it would actually create the opposite problem as `localhost://` will then be considered a scheme when the user didn't want that.

Maybe the main problem is that the URL parser accepts a blank port number and treats that as default? Because if it didn't, none of these "URLs" would've been accepted.

We could also do two passes over the url, where the first one doesn't allocate any memory but merely runs a sliding window over the url to detect scheme without considering schemebuf. The second pass will then know a) if a schema exists and b) whether it will fit in schemebuf. It would essentially be running `Curl_is_absolute_url(url, NULL, strlen(url)` or something along those lines.

Yes we could, but it doesn't really tell us what the right or expected behavior is. "hostname:/path" or "scheme://hostname". The current assumption is that when it doesn't look like a scheme it must be a host name...

We could possibly refuse a port number if the URL is scheme-less?

> Incorrect schema parser logic will allow malicious user to bypass protection mechanism and get access to the internal infrastructure of affected web servers.

How would that work? Surely such "protection mechanisms" would get done *before* curl operates on the URL so curl being more liberal would not actually be the problem.

It seems more likely to be a problem if you use curl itself as protection mechanism, expecting it to filter out bad URLs somehow and this "not treating very long schemes as schemes" take then surprises the following operation. But if you do it this way, then curl's scheme-less parsing is already an issue since it will allow strings through that aren't even URLs!

Can we come up with an actual possible attack/security flaw here?

Ok, I looked at the linked example.

That case assumes that the first URL filter doesn't care about the scheme at all but just verifies the host name and allows *any* scheme, and if the host name is okay it passes it on to curl. Which then treats the URL differently...

Thanks, that's exactly how that slide's example did it. It ignores the scheme from the whitelist parsing and just checks the host name, and then passes that on to curl to deal with no matter which scheme is used. it seems a little naive if you're really trying to whitelist URLs.

I'm still not convinced that this is a curl problem. I will totally agree that the example shown is a problematic one, but I am not yet entirely sold on the fact that this is curl's job. It *does* after all support "scheme-less URLs". It always did.

But okay, *if* we would say that this actually is a curl problem, then there would presumably be a **correct** way for curl to handle this. Which way is that? Clearly the parsing logic would need to be modified, but how?

I agree with the above line of thinking: "if this is wrong then there must be another way which is right". Putting the length of the request in this report aside for now, looking at the bigger picture. At the heart of this is how curl interprets what it considers a scheme-less URL like `foo:/bar` and `foo://bar`. Assuming there is a default port to use, these can both be interpreted as connecting to host `foo` accessing content at `/bar`. They can however also be considered to try and use scheme `foo` to connect to host `bar`. 

Looking at a couple of other implementations who also accept scheme-less URLs, this is how they handled the request `curl.se:/libcurl`:
* Firefox sends it to my defined search engine
* Chrome interprets it as the default port and goes to curl.se/libcurl/ on port 80
* Safari errors out saying: macOS doesn't recognize internet addresses starting with "curl.se:".
* wget translates the url to ftp://curl.se//libcurl and tries to connect on port 21

Trying these again with `curl.se://libcurl` instead:
* Firefox and Safari react exactly like for curl.se:/libcurl
* Chrome again interprets it as the default port and goes go curl.se/libcurl/ on port 80
* wget errors out with "Scheme missing"

Another attempt now with using `http:/curl.se/libcurl` and `http:/curl.se:/libcurl` which both yield:
* Firefox, Chrome and Safari all load http://curl.se/libcurl
* wget translates the URL to ftp://http//curl.se/libcurl and tries to connect to host http on port 21

curl will consider anything within the initial substring defined by `MAX_SCHEME_LEN` that looks like a scheme (essentially hunting for `:/`) as a scheme. If the "scheme marker" is beyond that substring, it will be treated as a hostname delineator with a default port, which IMO is a legitimate interpretation of this sequence of characters. Since the set of schemes known by curl at compile time is a finite known set, an upper limit of `MAX_SCHEME_LEN` isn't unreasonable.

I think curl is working as intended, albeit perhaps surprisingly, but that can be said for every program interpreting URLs given the sad state of URL standardization. Any security issue around using scheme-less URLs like this lies in the software issuing the request not validating input properly according to its business logic.

Reducing the surprise could be done by not accepting a default port for scheme-less URLs as mentioned upthread, that would nullify these URLs and would also be quite sensible since curl by definition doesn't know which protocol this is (apart from guessing one obvious one).

A longer term kind-of-sort-of workaround for this is giving libcurl the ability to restrict transfers to protocols which offer transport encryption based on a user-defined environment variable. That would make scheme-less URLs invalid since a a defined set of schemes would be mandated. That has been on my TODO list for some time, and I believe others have it on theirs as well.

Another fix which comes to mind here is limiting `MAX_SCHEME_LEN` based on the compilation options.  Disabling protocols when compiling curl will change the maximum possible scheme length, but we don't update `MAX_SCHEME_LEN` accordingly. Fixing that would require some preprocessor magic but it seems quite doable (and would shave a few bytes off the stack in stripped down libcurls for embedded use).

I agree with point that Chrome will open `curl.se://libcurl` by http but it should be mentioned that this behavior will not change with string length. Same is true for short and long host names. On the other hand curl rely on `MAX_SCHEME_LEN` variable and confuse users, specially when it was changed to 40. Ð¡ertainly provided sample software do not properly validate user input, but curl made it worse. Maybe it is good to restrict port guessing, at least for libcurl.
With "port guessing" I assume you mean that the parser accepts "nothing" as a port number even if a colon is present? Like in `localhost:/path` ?
Yes, I think case `localhost:/path` should return error port number is unknown.

I think that's a rather nice fix to this issue - we as we can still support it if a scheme is given to mimic the browsers. Shouldn't hurt very many users. It even hasn't been supported in curl for very long as @dgustafsson fixed that in [PR 3365](https://github.com/curl/curl/pull/3365) just two years ago.

I have a patch for this - coming up in a sec.

This then takes us back to the original question. Is this a curl security flaw? It is certainly a bit surprising and non-ideal. I'll ponder on it a bit more.
Here's a patch that introduces this change, and verifies it in test 1653 both with and without a scheme.
@bagder thank you for patch.

Here's a first draft of an advisory for this problem. If we act swiftly, we should be able to get this fix into the next release, planned to ship on December 9.

I haven't worked out what CWE to use...

---

scheme-less URL trickery
========================

Project curl Security Advisory, December 9th 2020 -
[Permalink](https://curl.se/docs/CVE-2020-XXXX.html)

VULNERABILITY
-------------

A long scheme on a URL can be used to trick curl to instead use it as host
name.

curl operates on "URLs", but as a special shortcut it also supports URLs
without the scheme. For example just a plain host name. Such input isn't at
all by any standards an actual URL or URI; curl was made to handle such input
to mimic how browsers work. curl "guesses" what scheme the given name is meant
to have, and for most names it will go with HTTP.

Further, a URL can provide a specific port number using a colon and a port
number following the host name, like `hostname:80` and the path then follows
the port number: `hostname:80/path`. To complicate matters, the port number
can be blank, and the path can start with more than one slash:
`hostname://path`.

curl's logic that determines if a given input string has a scheme present
checks the first 40 bytes of the string for a `://` sequence and if that is
deemed not present, curl determines that this is a scheme-less host name.

This means `[39-letter string]://` as input is treated as a URL with a scheme
and a scheme that curl doesn't know about and therefore is rejected as an
input, while `[40-letter string]://` is considered a host name with a blank
port number field and a path that starts with double slash.

This scheme detecting heuristics comes unexpected to users and isn't
documented and as such opens up for mistakes and wrong assumptions. An example
is for cases where a function is allow-listing host names with a generic URL
parser before it passes it on to curl to act on. A generic URL parser that
accepts all schemes and just verifies the host name:

    if( acceptable_hostname( get_url_host( $URL ) ) )
    {
       pass_on_url_to_curl ( $URL )
    }

Example URL input that might pass such a filter but works with curl using the
longer name as host name:

`aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa.haxx.se://dn.se`

We are not aware of any exploit of this flaw.

INFO
----

This flaw has existed in curl since commit
[d8607da1a68f2482](https://github.com/curl/curl/commit/d8607da1a68f2482)
introduced in curl 7.64.0.

The Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) project has assigned the name
CVE-2020-XXXX to this issue.

CWE-XXX: 

Severity: Low

AFFECTED VERSIONS
-----------------

- Affected versions: libcurl 7.64.0 to and including 7.73.0
- Not affected versions: libcurl < 7.64.0 and libcurl >= 7.74.0

Also note that libcurl is used by many applications, and not always
advertised as such.

THE SOLUTION
------------

curl now rejects scheme-less inputs without digits following the colon. Such a
sequency is however still accepted if the URL is specified with a scheme, to
better match what browsers accept.

A [fix for CVE-2020-XXXX](https://curl.se/.patch)

RECOMMENDATIONS
--------------

We suggest you take one of the following actions immediately, in order of
preference:

 A - Upgrade curl to version 7.74.0

 B - Make sure you verify the scheme as well, not just host names
 
TIMELINE
--------

This issue was first reported to the curl project on December 3, 2020.

This advisory was posted on December 9th 2020.

CREDITS
-------

This issue was reported by d4d. Patch by Daniel Stenberg.

Thanks a lot!
**CWE-20: Improper Input Validation** is the best CWE I can find but it doesn't seem like a perfect fit: https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/20.html ...
@d4d: please let me know how you would like to be credited in the advisory.

This problem strikes me as a variant of the one that prompted the creation of the curl_url_* API. Assuming this scheme vs host detection is done within that API, then this strikes me as essentially the same problem as applications and libcurl parsing URLs differently. As long as applications take precautions against this problem (i.e., they use curl_api_* to perform URL parsing) then this isn't an issue. In short: is this really a new security issue or just a variant of one we've seen (and fixed) before?

I agree it is the exact same kind of issue and a fix for this issue is of  course to not mix parsers as there will always be a risk with doing that.

Still, we should probably just not consider a URL that looks like a scheme as scheme-less, for better consistency and less surprises.

I think the main question regarding this issue, that I have a hard time to yes to, is this:

**Is this in itself a security problem in curl?**

As both @dfandrich and @dgustafsson have touched: parsing URLs is notoriously inconsistent between implementations, partly because there are multiple and incompatible standards. Thus, running different parsers and assuming that they end up with the exact same result is futile and, unfortunately, naive.

As of now, I cannot consider this issue a curl security problem. I still think we should apply the patch I've suggested to reduce the risk of these confusions.

Hi! I'm ok with **CREDITS** `This issue was reported by d4d. Patch by Daniel Stenberg.`
Thank you!

Okay, thanks, but as I said in my previous comment I will go with considering this issue as a plain bug, not a security problem. The security implications are not there because of curl but because of the mixed/combined URL parsers. The state of URLs will continue to make mixing URL parsers a fragile thing, with and without this curl fix.

I'll still credit you proper in the upcoming pull-request of course.
I will post the patch as a public pull request later today.
https://github.com/curl/curl/pull/6283
Thanks a lot for this report. We continue this work in the PR mentioned above.
@badger thank you for all your hard work
To let more people see how we reasoned.
